title: Adding transform references
body:
Two references were added in separate commits:
- caching-coffeeify
- es6ify

title: Updated readme to explain expose capabilities
Unicode characters get messed up
body:
For example d3.js uses some weird unicode characters as variable names:
https://github.com/mbostock/d3/blob/91d35b4205d4ef150c61c415b7379404bced7267/d3.js#L1283

Browserify outputs this as

```
var Ï€ = Math.PI, Îµ = 1e-6, d3_radians = Ï€ / 180, d3_degrees = 180 / Ï€;
```

Which is syntax error.

Terrible practice by d3, but this should not break Browserify.

title: add enchilada tool to readme
body: Enchilada is express middleware to browserify on the fly.

title: List express middleware in readme
body:
I've now finished version 1 of [browserify-middleware](https://github.com/ForbesLindesay/browserify-middleware).  I think it represents a really nice easy to use middleware solution for browserify.

P.S. I hope it's OK that I re-used and modified your readme art.  If not I will of course remove it.

title: Unexpected end of input from child folder, fine from parent
body:
Well, when I run browserify from a parent folder, it works fine. When run from inside a folder, I get this error.

Here is a pastebin: http://pastebin.com/vsShkEUb

The index.js file simply has this code:

```
"use strict";

console.log('test');
```

Even adding some stuff doesn't change much to the error. Works fine from parent folder, doesn't from child.

title: Add link to Liveify source transform
body: I've forked coffeeify and adapted it to compile [LiveScript](https://github.com/gkz/LiveScript).

title: A method to visualize a tree of bundled packages
body:
There's a "problem" w/ Node modules being included several times in bundle either because of wrong installation procedure or because of requirements for different versions from different packages (lost a hour while debugging a bundle w/ two versions of backbone included so instanceof deep in the backbone code base went crazy).

I think it would be nice to browserify to expose an info about a graph of packages used in a bundle. This would allow some external tool visualise such a graph in way like npm does after installation procedure.

title: Support for paths
body:
I'm not sure if this is in the scope of Browserify, or even if it already exists (I have had a good look around).

In RequireJS you can [configure paths to map to different locations](http://requirejs.org/docs/api.html#config-paths) (not aliasing files but directories). For example, I have a `components` folder which is three directories above all of my JavaScript. This means that I constantly have require statements such as:
`require('../../../components/[component-name]')`.

If I could somehow map `components` to `../../../components`, then I could do:
`require('components/[component-name]').`

I'm sure there's a good reason that this doesn't exist, but I am curious as to why. The only way I can see of doing this with the current API is using `bundle.fake` (not documented still?) or every desired file in the `components` folder, but this is why I would like path mappings.

title: Cannot lazy load multiple bundles
Add rfileify to transforms list
body: https://github.com/ForbesLindesay/rfileify works just like brfs but for calls to `rfile`, `ruglify` etc.

title: source maps should be exportable to file
body:
while i appreciate the recent addition of the --debug option to add source maps into the file as base64 it would be nice to have an option of writing it to a file instead. 

If that where possible tools like uglify js could use it as an input to create their own source maps on top and we could have source maps all the way back from minified code to the original sources.

title: Fix a bug with b.require if {expose:true}
body:
If I expose a file without giving a name ({expose:true}), hoping for it to use the file hash, a bug may happen inside the bundle : the file is exposed with hash, but internally referenced with id number.

At https://github.com/substack/node-browserify/blob/e7fc5cb470a3bef22328f69e5c5461549dbede36/index.js#L217
If the exposed file was already seen in a dependency, an id number was generated and the hash is not used here.

title: Add hbsfy to source transforms list
Pass extensions opts key to module-deps and browser-resolve calls
body:
This is due #326 — to allow requiring non-js files w/o extensions while using browserify.

This pull request depends on shtylman/node-browser-resolve#12 and substack/module-deps#5 and doesn't have tests while I'll add some if you are willing to accepts such functionality. Please note that I don't want this pull request to be merged, this is just to describe an idea and provide a use-case for pull requests mentioned above — API implemented now is quite verbose and dirty.

Basically it allows to specify which file extensions modules can have, so instead of considering only `.js` files it could be configured to to look for `.coffee` files for example:

```
browserify --extension '.coffee' --extension '.mustache' ...
```

So you can write simply `require('module')` for requiring `module.coffee`.

I think that CoffeeScript (actually same goes for TypeScript and Roy and others langs compiled to js) community can benefit a lot from this because it is natural to think of coffeescript modules as interchangeable with "native" javascript modules — even Node allows loading coffee modules via `require.extensions` registry.

title: Warn when bundling multiple versions of the same dependency
body:
Lets do this by example. I have a project where I'm using Backbone and Underscore libraries and I happen to have following dependencies in package.json:

``` javascript
"dependencies": {
  "backbone": "1.0.0",
  "underscore": "1.3.0"
}
```

Now because the backbone module depends on underscore 1.4.3 or later - npm installs two underscores to node_modules, 1.3.0 to the top level and 1.4.3 privately to backbone. Which means that browserify will also bundle two underscore versions in to the bundle. But if the versions are compatible npm removes the private version from backbone and the bundle will get only one version of underscore.

This is actually really great feature if my app has a hard dependency on backbone 1.0.0 and underscore 1.3.0, but most often this is just a mistake because I forgot to update underscore dependency after updating backbone.

So I would love to see Browserify warn about this case.

title: Cyclical requires will return the correct exports object reference on a cache hit.
body:
When doing a cyclical requires the current implementation had exposed module names alias to hashed file names by creating a function that performed a requires to the hashed module name. When the hashed module code ran and made a cyclical requires, the local module resolution resolved to the name of the aliased module.

That aliased module had a separately created exports object reference, and because we were still in the middle of a require, that exports object reference had not been updated yet, so we were getting a cache hit to the wrong exports object reference.

The fix I am proposing is to have the local module resolution resolve directly to the hashed file name module which will return the correct exports object reference on the cache hit. The old method of calling the aliased module introduces new code into the middle of the module execution and causes this side effect.

This fix fixes issue #333 which I submitted.

title: require does not return the correct exports object references for cyclical requires
body:
When doing a cyclical requires, the cached require hit of a module that is in the process of being loaded does not return a reference to the correct exports object.

The node documentation outlines the scenario of a cyclical requires:

http://nodejs.org/api/modules.html#modules_cycles

In the scenario, module a requires module b, which requires module a. If we start by executing a, when we require b, we enter into module b and start running that code. When  b requires a it is supposed to load the exports object from module a.

In the current implementation the exposed modules call requires on a hash that then resolves to the module function. I'm assuming this is to allow multiple require paths to resolve to the same module.

However, this has the side effect that each named module has a different module and exports object which does not get populated until the hashed module completes executing. This means that the exposed exports object during the execution of a module is not the correct reference to the exports object until after the module has completed executing. This breaks cyclical requires.

title: Question: 'request' package supported with browserify?
Relative module names
body:
When executing `browserify` with the JS API, the output module name will just be the path of the entry file that is passed when instantiating `browserify`.

Sometimes it is desired that a module path name is relative to a mounted directory. This can be achieved by executing `browserify` from the command line and providing a relative path name for the entry file, but this flexibility is not always achievable when using the API. What are the options for achieving this?

I would like to propose a `basePath` option that all module names will be relative to.

title: How to add code (in a string) instead of a file path
body:
I need the option to add code as string instead of a file. This is because I generate some code in runtime, that will be used in client side. There is also the problem that a lot of hosting services for node are not really friendly to write local files (heroku for example). 

I need this, and I want to contribute, so my question is: how should I do it? a plugin? as a pull request? I imagine this feature is not really needed in browserify core, so this is more a feedback suggestion than anything

PS: I realize this is not really an issue, but I wasn't sure were to post it :)

title: browserify.transform returns browserfiy instance to support chaining
use streams2
body: I dunno if this is possible, but node current stable users will get old streams if they try to browserify stuff now

title: browserify -r .
body:
A bit confused about this aspect of browserify: I want to develop modules that do not require their users to install / develop with browserify.

Browserify is part of the way there: `browserify -r foo` creates a bundle that lets users use `require(foo)`, but `browserify -r .` breaks. Ideally `browserify -r .` would create the same - a package that provides `require('foo')` where foo is the module you're developing.

The colon-targeting gets us part of the way there, so +1 on that, but `-r .` is the syntax I would guess (read this-dir's package.json and build a package with that requirement).

title: transformers require using extension in require() invocations
body:
This is awful.

I enjoy having the freedom of writing in CoffeeScript or JavaScript, and making use of the require() hack in node to load .coffee files automagically.  Or, if I want, compile to JS.  Code works either way.

If I want to use transformers, now I need to reference CoffeeScript modules with a ".coffee" extension in the require() parameter, which means compiling to JS won't work anymore.

Seems like what needs to happen is:
- transformers should indicate extensions they consider valid module source
- those extensions should be taken into account when resolving modules

title: using transformers emits multiple sourceMappingURL entries
body:
Given issue https://github.com/substack/node-browserify/issues/322, seems like we want the transformers to **NOT** place the sourceMappingsURL inline, but add them to a single sourceMap file produced with the bundle.

Or should we punt on this issue, and say this is just a requirement for a new slicer/dicer sourceMap utility that could take what browserify currently gives us, and generates something different.  Like my [thingee](https://gist.github.com/pmuellr/5143384), only considerably more complex. :-)

title: Added the ability to require dependencies relative to the cwd
Make module.parent available.
body: Fix for #318

title: sourcemaps out-of-line
body:
The sourcemaps via data-url is a neat trick, which allows you to deliver a debuggable wad to the browser without requiring subsequent network accesses to get the map.

Seems a little non-standard.

Also, it increases the amount of data that needs to be sent by 33%, since it's base64'd.

But a bigger problem is that when some editors try to open files with these in them, they die - TextMate and Sublime Text 2 anyway.  Click on the file, now you gots to Force Quit your editor.  Locks up with 100% CPU for longer than I was willing to wait for it to "finish" (30 sec).  :-(  My test is with a sourcemap wad that's 242KB (base64'd).

I'd like to see an option to split the sourcemap data into a separate file, and then also let me indicate what the URL to that file will be.  The default file name would be [outputFile].map, and the default URL would be that string as well.

Please do keep using the sourcesContent field to ship the source IN the sourcemap, because I'd like to limit the # of URLs I have to keep in sync between server and dev to 1 - the sourcemap itself, and don't really care how big the sourcemap file is.

title: adding sourcemap support to browserify
body:
This still depends on my fork of browser-pack.
So we first would need to merge [this](https://github.com/substack/browser-pack/pull/4), publish as new version and the nchange the dependency.

At this point only a `--debug` flag is supported which inlines sources by default and puts sourceRootURL at the root of the file system.
In the future we should support more flags, to opt out of inlining sources (keep bundle smaller) and to point sourceRootURL wherever we like.

I'll add these in a later PR, at this point I wanted to get the minimum functionality in.

title: Implement colon target behavior for -r
body:
The documentation states:

> Optionally use a colon separator to set the target.

This patch makes that work.

title: `module.parent` is `null` when it should not be
added debug option to use sourceURL
body: See issue https://github.com/substack/node-browserify/issues/299

title: Permit to use a different directory for cache file
body: While trying to run a nodejs software using browserify 1.X on Openshift, I found out that ~ is not writeable for security reason. So in order to put the cache somewhere else, I have added another environment variable so I can choose where to put the cache file.

title: browserify browserify
body:
for a code editor that I'm working on I would like to generate bundles in the browser. here is an example workflow:
- user enters `require('foo')` into the editor. I make an XHR request to NPM and store `foo` in the browser (using `fs-browserify` or similar).
- then I take the entire entry file that they are editing and run it through browserify, then execute it and show them the output
- when they make small edits to their program, as long as they dont enter any new `require()` calls I can update the output without making additional network requests

what would be the hardest part of making this possible?

title: When bundling files encoded as UTF-8 with a byte order marker, BOMs are retained
body:
Some UTF-8 encoded files include a byte order marker at the beginning. These are retained when bundling causing a **SyntaxError: illegal character** error when the script is executed.

Although you're not using fs.readFileSync it's a similar issue to https://github.com/joyent/node/issues/1918

title: smart multi bundles
body:
Creating this pull request so we can discuss the best approach for both API surface and feature implementation. See the added test if it is not clear from my comments about what the final bundle output benefits are.

.require(bundle) allows for the capture of all files which this bundle
might contain. Previously, just the file which you did
.require({external: true}) was the one not bundled. This is even more
efficient when using external bundles.

title: Client side browserify
body: It would be nice if there were a browser based API for browserify, so that web text editors could incorporate it into a workflow.

title: Throws on some malformed packages
body:
Found after:

```
npm install --save https://github.com/marijnh/CodeMirror/archive/v3.1.tar.gz
browserify -r codemirror
```

```
/Users/tmcw/.nvm/v0.8.21/lib/node_modules/browserify/index.js:20
    return crypto.createHash('md5').update(what).digest('base64').slice(0, 6);
                                    ^
TypeError: Not a string or buffer
    at hash (/Users/tmcw/.nvm/v0.8.21/lib/node_modules/browserify/index.js:20:37)
    at Browserify.require (/Users/tmcw/.nvm/v0.8.21/lib/node_modules/browserify/index.js:58:34)
    at /Users/tmcw/.nvm/v0.8.21/lib/node_modules/browserify/node_modules/browser-resolve/index.js:139:9
    at module.exports.file (/Users/tmcw/.nvm/v0.8.21/lib/node_modules/browserify/node_modules/browser-resolve/node_modules/resolve/lib/async.js:44:14)
    at process (/Users/tmcw/.nvm/v0.8.21/lib/node_modules/browserify/node_modules/browser-resolve/node_modules/resolve/lib/async.js:98:43)
    at module.exports.splitRe (/Users/tmcw/.nvm/v0.8.21/lib/node_modules/browserify/node_modules/browser-resolve/node_modules/resolve/lib/async.js:107:21)
    at load (/Users/tmcw/.nvm/v0.8.21/lib/node_modules/browserify/node_modules/browser-resolve/node_modules/resolve/lib/async.js:49:43)
    at /Users/tmcw/.nvm/v0.8.21/lib/node_modules/browserify/node_modules/browser-resolve/node_modules/resolve/lib/async.js:55:22
    at module.exports.isFile (/Users/tmcw/.nvm/v0.8.21/lib/node_modules/browserify/node_modules/browser-resolve/node_modules/resolve/lib/async.js:16:47)
    at Object.oncomplete (fs.js:297:15)
```

Possibly this is a malformed package? In any case, might be an area for browserify to more gracefully handle failures.

title: Bundle js and coffee together needs custom transform function
body:
I was last last working on my project which uses browserify some 2 weeks ago and browserifying stopped working after it'd update.

I really liked how 1.18.0 handled coffee. When I compile now I either get esprima for coffee or coffee error for js files.

Am I doing something wrong or that's your philosophy now to have separate bundles for these?

title: better handling of esprima errors (improvement)
body:
esprima considers script level returns illegal. As an example it doesn't like [this](https://github.com/thlorenz/thlorenz.com/blob/efba2fecd4f680adab5e8e7619126d87dd455e5e/public/js/navigation.js#L52)

That in itself is not a problem - wrapping in self-invoking function solves this, but it is hard to figure out where the problem is, if all I get is this stacktrace when running the browserify build:

```
/Users/thlorenz/Dropboxes/Gmail/Dropbox/dev/javascript/projects/thlorenz.com/node_modules/browserify/node_modules/module-deps/node_modules/detective/node_modules/esprima/esprima.js:3859
            throw e;
                  ^
Error: Line 52: Illegal return statement
    at throwError (/Users/thlorenz/Dropboxes/Gmail/Dropbox/dev/javascript/projects/thlorenz.com/node_modules/browserify/node_modules/module-deps/node_modules/detective/node_modules/esprima/esprima.js:1161:21)
    at throwErrorTolerant (/Users/thlorenz/Dropboxes/Gmail/Dropbox/dev/javascript/projects/thlorenz.com/node_modules/browserify/node_modules/module-deps/node_modules/detective/node_modules/esprima/esprima.js:1172:24)
    at parseReturnStatement (/Users/thlorenz/Dropboxes/Gmail/Dropbox/dev/javascript/projects/thlorenz.com/node_modules/browserify/node_modules/module-deps/node_modules/detective/node_modules/esprima/esprima.js:2476:13)
    at parseStatement (/Users/thlorenz/Dropboxes/Gmail/Dropbox/dev/javascript/projects/thlorenz.com/node_modules/browserify/node_modules/module-deps/node_modules/detective/node_modules/esprima/esprima.js:2752:24)
    at parseIfStatement (/Users/thlorenz/Dropboxes/Gmail/Dropbox/dev/javascript/projects/thlorenz.com/node_modules/browserify/node_modules/module-deps/node_modules/detective/node_modules/esprima/esprima.js:2191:22)
    at parseStatement (/Users/thlorenz/Dropboxes/Gmail/Dropbox/dev/javascript/projects/thlorenz.com/node_modules/browserify/node_modules/module-deps/node_modules/detective/node_modules/esprima/esprima.js:2750:24)
    at parseSourceElement (/Users/thlorenz/Dropboxes/Gmail/Dropbox/dev/javascript/projects/thlorenz.com/node_modules/browserify/node_modules/module-deps/node_modules/detective/node_modules/esprima/esprima.js:3044:24)
    at parseSourceElements (/Users/thlorenz/Dropboxes/Gmail/Dropbox/dev/javascript/projects/thlorenz.com/node_modules/browserify/node_modules/module-deps/node_modules/detective/node_modules/esprima/esprima.js:3082:29)
    at parseProgram (/Users/thlorenz/Dropboxes/Gmail/Dropbox/dev/javascript/projects/thlorenz.com/node_modules/browserify/node_modules/module-deps/node_modules/detective/node_modules/esprima/esprima.js:3096:19)
    at Object.parse (/Users/thlorenz/Dropboxes/Gmail/Dropbox/dev/javascript/projects/thlorenz.com/node_modules/browserify/node_modules/module-deps/node_modules/detective/node_modules/esprima/esprima.js:3843:23)
```

It would be nice to catch this error and let me know which file it was parsing when this error occurred.
In my particular case it was trivial to find, but on a larger project it may be a nightmare.

I also think that wrapping the entire code in a self invoking function before parsing it would prevent these errors from occurring. If I'm understanding correctly the parsing is done in order to find the `require` statements which would still work then.

title: require doesn't handle relative paths properly
body:
@shtylman informed me that full paths should be used.

This needs to be outlined in the readme and a better error should be raised (i.e. tell me I need to use full paths).

Same goes for `add`, except that there it is even worse since I get no error at all, instead my entire root folder seems to be included in the bundle when I give it a relative path.

Naturally, if `add` is removed from the readme since it is for backward compat anyways, that's not a problem and needs no fixing.

[This](https://github.com/substack/node-browserify/blob/master/index.js#L50) seems to be the problem for relative paths working unexpectedly.

If used from a build script deriving root from the parent module makes more sense [see here](https://github.com/thlorenz/browserify-shim/blob/master/index.js#L6).

title: Support for aliases
body: It would be cool to have a way to define aliased for modules so I can define `jquery` to be `jquery-browserify` or `./jquery` for example.

title: smaller bundle sizes when externals used
body:
Instead of adding dummy passthrough code for externals, set the require
key to directly reference the external. This leads to smaller bundle
sizes when external files are referenced.

title: Regression of ignoreMissing feature
body: This option has stopped working in latest release. In sources i see some inconsistency in defaults: in `bundle` it defaults to false, later in `deps` it ignored if it not undefined, but set to true in case of undefined.

title: node v0.8.21 & npm v1.2.11 trying to install browserify v2.3.1
body:
Hi,

I've tried to install the latest version of browserify on the mac and windows 8 and they both fail to install.

They both seem to start falling over at this point:

npm WARN `git config --get remote.origin.url` returned wrong result (git://github.com/shtylman/node-detective.git) execvp(): No such file or directory
npm http 304 https://registry.npmjs.org/falafel
npm ERR! git clone git://github.com/shtylman/node-detective.git execvp(): No such file or directory
npm ERR! Error: ENOENT, chown '/usr/local/lib/node_modules/browserify/node_modules/insert-module-globals/node_modules/lexical-scope/node_modules/falafel/example'

Thanks,

John

title: Huge performance degradation since 1.18.0
body: I see huge performance degradation on 2.2.5 (4.78s) compared to 1.18.0 (0.23s). That way I cannot develop with browserify 2.x.

title: browserify.register() - how to browserify IcedCoffeeScript now
body:
Hi - I've been happily using browserify as part of my build process with IcedCoffeeScript, typically like so:

``` coffee-script
  b = browserify()
  b.register '.iced', (body) -> icedCoffeeScript.compile body, {runtime: "browserify"}
  # etc.
```

(It was a very pleasant switch from stitch.)

But this stopped working for me with the latest npm package (I believe in the change to 2.0+).  Is there another way to do this while continuing to get your updates? If so, I'm not seeing it in the readme.

If there's not an answer, can browserify simply support IcedCoffeeScript directly? I assume this is identical to supporting CoffeeScript, just a different compile function.

title: Emit @sourceURL tags in bundles (return ---debug command line option)
body: I think this is essential feature.

title: Require fixes
body: Comments in commits.

title: Handle files started with hashbang
body:
Some files in node may start with line like `#!/usr/bin/env node`, it would be great if it would not throw an error

```
Line 1: Unexpected token ILLEGAL
```

title: Optimizing static bundle size?
body:
The static bundling in browserify 2 looks very promising. However, one of my concerns is that it will increase the code size of the generated bundle as compared to simple concatentation, due to the boilerplate for each require'able file.

I expect it is possible to reduce the size of generated static bundle to levels comparable to concatentation, but this might break the design goals of browserify (say by not allowing bundled files to be require'd from outside the bundle). So I wanted to see your thoughts on this issue before I considered taking a crack at it myself.

As a contrived example, consider the following file, length.js:

``` js
module.exports = function(array) {
  return array.length;
};
```

Ignoring the fixed overhead (196 bytes) for the bundle, the incremental size of just this file minified in the static bundle is about 61 bytes:

``` js
1:[function(_,m){m.exports=function(a){return a.length}},{}],
```

In a non-browserify world, the length function might instead be implemented as:

``` js
function length(array) {
  return array.length;
}
```

Which minifies to 30 bytes:

``` js
function l(a){return a.length}
```

So, for the purpose of discussion, we can estimate that there is a per-file overhead of about 30 bytes when using static bundling versus concatenation. (Of course, building custom bundles using only the needed code via static analysis would produce a bundle that is far smaller than concatenating everything, but for this discussion I’m concerned with the default case, say where d3js.org provides a pre-built bundle with default functionality for convenience.)

If I extend this 30 bytes to D3’s 200 or so separate files, the resulting overhead is about 6KB, which represents about a 5% overhead on top of the 124KB d3.min.js. This isn’t huge, but at the same time, if I can avoid the overhead, that would make me happy.

One approach to reducing the size of the static bundle is to try to make it equivalent to concatenation. This might not be possible with certain edge cases, such as circular require's, but it wouldn’t be hard for a common usage pattern. For example, the minified length.js in the bundle might appear as:

``` js
L=function(a){return a.length};
```

This is only 31 bytes, identical to concatenation. And subsequently, all instances of `require("length")` would be replaced inline with `L`. (In practice, browserify could use long names for each required module, such as _require_length, and then uglifyjs could reduce them to minimal variable names without collision.) Assuming that all bundled modules are listed in dependency-order, this should function equivalently to the current approach, but be quite a bit smaller.

I guess the biggest downside of this approach is that non-exported local variables in the file would need to be namespaced so as to avoid leaking into other modules. This might be challenging to implement and would further increase the size of the non-minified bundle.

Anyway, curious to hear your thoughts. I might still be willing to go-ahead given all the other benefits, but I always like to have my cake and eat it too.

title: Pass opts to bundle
body: This fixes ignoring params on bundling.

title: Transpiler Support
body:
I've been hunting through the new 2.0 code trying to figure out how to make browserify use a transpiler, but there doesn't seem to be a clean place for adding a `compile` call.

As far as I can tell, I'd have to set the [`detective` option in node-required](https://github.com/shtylman/node-required/blob/master/index.js#L17) to a function that transpiles the source before passing it to the regular [node-detective](https://github.com/substack/node-detective), but [the call to module-deps (and thus to node-required) in browserify](https://github.com/substack/node-browserify/blob/a4e46f282bb1f02e382eb49daeea73fea078c0fb/index.js#L111-L117) doesn't have a way to pass in a custom detective function.

Additionally, I'd have to change the [source retrieval in module-deps](https://github.com/substack/module-deps/blob/master/index.js#L47) to use the transpiled code, and since the source is read separately from `required`, I'd need to modify module-deps even further to alleviate the need for redundant transpilations.

title: Modules designed to work client or server side
body:
I noticed that browserify doesn't work with modules like revalidator that don't use common js in a browser environment. Revalidator has this code:

```
(typeof(window) === 'undefined' ? module.exports : (window.json = window.json || {}))
```

so when used with browserify in the browser the revalidator module is defined, but empty. 

I'd like to create a pull request for revalidator to enable it to work with browserify. Is there a standard way to make these modules work? Specifically I need to detect if the module is being required by browserify and change the export object. Thanks.

title: b.link(src, dest) API for using external libraries
Multiple Bundles are not working
body:
Currently the multiple bundles example only works because of a minor mistake in the build.sh, as shown [here](https://github.com/rkusa/node-browserify/commit/92297922eae1c0fe44bcc8be85054c1bce636d08).

After fixing the build.sh, the example does not work anymore. It throws `Uncaught TypeError: undefined is not a function` because `require('./robot')` returns an undefined.

Btw, I really like version 2 of browserify, good work!

title: b.fake(name, path) API for overwriting modules with alternative implementation
body:
Added `b.fake(moduleName, alternativePath)` method:

It allows to replace some `moduleName` module with alternative implementation located at
`alternativePath`. For example:

``` javascript
b.fake('express', __dirname + '/fake-express.js');
b.fake('fs', __dirname + '/client-side-fs.js');
```

`b.expose('express', alterPath)` isn't worked as expected. Maybe it's a bug, or just misunderstanding of api, but i really need possibility to overwrite some modules (both native and not native) with fake implementation.

title: Util module is missing
body: `require('util')` returns empty module

title: Specify files to also bundle in package.json
body:
It would be awesome, if browserify would also bundle files, that are defined in the package.json.

For example if I have the following app.js

```
var mymodule = require("mymodule");
mymodule.doSomeStuff();
```

And the package.json of "mymodule" would contain a property like this:

```
{
...
"browser-dependencies":["somefile.js"]
...
}
```

When bundling the app, browserify should then _prepend_ all the files that are specified like this to the bundlefile.

This would be really useful, if one want's to depend on code that is not in the node.js-module-format.

Thanks for thinking about it :)

**Update**

After thinking about it, it's maybe better to add an "include" function. The difference between include and require would be, that the included file would not get parsed & interpreted in any way, it just would get executed on a global level when include is called. To detect which files need to get included, you could do it the same way like with require, just search for it in the sourcecode.

Using this approach, you'd have better control about when to execute the script, instead of just executing it before everything else.

What do you think?

...you maybe ask yourself why I'm requesting such a thing. The answer to this: I want to depend on the "ace"-editor by ajaxorg, but since they don't have a node-style package that I could browserify, the user of my library would also need to link the ace scripts separately. But I want to bundle all of them right into one script file, and I want it to happen automatically, so when someone requires my library and bundles it using browserify, that should be all he has to do. All dependencies should be bundled.

title: util + JSON.parse
body: Should built_ins/utils and friends use [jsonify](https://github.com/substack/jsonify) instead of `JSON.parse` and `JSON.stringify`

title: consider shimming Function.prototype.bind
Support `require("console")` like in node
body: Just added a dependency on [console-browserify](https://github.com/Raynos/console-browserify).

title: different versions of generated code with browserify and the node module
body:
Hi,

I've been using browserify for some time as a middleware in my web app.

Now I wanted to remove the middleware and generate the file with the cli tool.

The two files differ significantly and can't be exchanged :(

How can I generate a file on the cli that is the same as the one generated by the browserify middleware?

title: update streams code to match 0.8
body:
This matches exactly what is in v0.8 now on joyent/node

I need this for the `if (dest.destroy) dest.destroy()`

title: Ignore if missing
body:
Sometimes packages require too much stuff in dev-mode (devDependencies), and also have separate source branch for test coverage ('./lib-cov/...'). For example, in jade module, which is working great if i browserify it using this command:

```
browserify client-side.js -o public/javascripts/compound.js -i module\
 -i ./lib-cov/jade -i ./lib-cov/stylus -i http -i markdown -i discount\
 -i markdown-js -i marked
```

It would be awesome if this command could be shortened to:

```
browserify client-side.js -o public/javascripts/compound.js --ignore-missing
```

If it works for you i'd be happy to come up with pull request. Thanks for awesome library!

title: Fix //@sourceURL in IE
body: Apparently `//@sourceURL` breaks IE sometimes. The jQuery guys [have run into this](http://bugs.jquery.com/ticket/13274) and have [a nice fix](http://bugs.jquery.com/ticket/13274#comment:6). Also @thlorenz has apparently run into this in real life.

title: Question: Using a library that is written for both node and browser
body:
I was looking for a solution that would allow me to pack my library project as a bundle- for both nodejs and browser javascript - when I stumbled upon node-browserify. Now I have functions that are just for serverside which I told them to throw an error if module is undefined (that's how I check if I'm using node or clientside for now). And the bundled source has required modules such as underscore. 

When I browserify the library I wrote I want:
- The dependencies added in the file
- Don't want to get `require is undefined` errors in browser
- Be able to call my function on browser

When I did browserify I got the following [pastebin](http://pastebin.com/ZTBBn5wQ):
- When I copy pasted the code into the js console in chrome I saw that neither `require` nor `_` were defined
- I did not know how to use my functions or how to call them

Is browserify what should be used for writing both server-side js and clientside js? Or does it work in some other way? Or am I doing something wrong?

If you would enlighten me I would be grateful. I'm sure require works just fine in nodejs but could you please give me some more examples of how to use the bundle.js in browser?

Just to clarify a few things about my code, it currently has only a couple functions; one of them uses `fs` and that utility function is only for nodejs, and others are things like deepmerging arrays/objects which can be used for both server and browser side. I just want to make it easy to package it up by making the bundle.js have all the dependencies (underscore) and upon packaging I don't want to be making two versions for browser-side and nodejs; instead I want the One js file to be automatically gotten ready for both sides.

title: needs a zlib shim
body: trying to browserify something that has `require('zlib')` in it doesn't work so having `zlib` be an empty object would be nice

title: Remove Coffeescript from core
body: See #236 for the new solution (a plugin).

title: More recent version of node-querystring
body: Didn't manage to run browserling tests though (even before making any changes)

title: inside wrap.js syntaxError are emitted on process.nextTick()
body:
Since syntaxErrors are emitted on process.nextTick() and bundle will return code even if there were syntax errors, process.nextTick seems to be too late to notify the application about the error (spent half a day, because this assumption was not true).

I fixed my local code by removing the process.nextTick and didn't see any odd side effects, but I'm left wondering what was the reason to delay the events in the first place, and if there is no particular reason, I can send a pull request to fix this

title: Option to include ES5 shims ?
body: Unfortunately there are still browser engines that don't implement ES5 features like `Function.prototype.bind` or `Object.create` etc... Manual inclusion of [es5-shim](https://github.com/kriskowal/es5-shim) is not a perfect option since one needs to explicitly require it before anything else is executed. It would be great if packages could claim compatibility with specific engines and then browserify included shims that are unavailable for those engines.

title: Fix timers for phantomjs
body: #255 Assumed bind will be used only in chrome, but as @Raynos [pointed out](https://github.com/substack/node-browserify/pull/255#issuecomment-11786105) PhantomJS also requires window as `this` pseudo variable and it does not has `Function.prototype.bind` either.

title: Shim `Object.keys` so assert works in oldIE.
return cached instance when requiring aliased module
body: previously, if, for example, aliasing `jquery` to `jquary-browserify`, `require('jquery')` would always return a new instance of `jquery-browserify`, which is not how node's `require` works. This patch properly returns the same instance for aliased modules.

title: Use UTC format for last-modified header
body: I changed the last-modified header to use the ISO format instead of a local specific format. Now, some reverse proxies, like Varnish, can send a 304 Not Modified response if the client has the bundle in cache.

title: Sourcemap support
body: It would be awesome if browserify could create source-maps for the generated files.

title: Watch should not exit on error
body: If there's an error while in _watch mode_ browserify exits. I think it would be better to just notify the error and keep watching files for changes. In that way a user doesn't have to restart the script every time he commits an error.

title: Expose filename when syntax error occurs
body:
When a syntax error occurs the bundle object emits a `syntaxError` event with an object that includes some info such as the line number, but it does tell you which file the syntax error occurred in. The change is pretty minor and basically sets `err.file` to the filename before the event is emitted.

I am not sure if this the right approach. I saw that there is a `wrap.errors` object, but it doesn't seem that the `wrap` object is exposed through the bundle and even if it was it doesn't look like all errors are added to that `wrap.errors` object as my `bundle.ok` is `true` even after a syntax error is emitted.

title: Preserve path for individual file requires
body:
Was having an issue where if I did something like:

`browserify( { require : [ './lib/x.js', './lib/y.js' ] } );`

they would get defined as '/x.js' instead of './lib/x.js'. Wrote a quick patch that preserves the requested path.

title: Add timers module.
body:
In addon-sdk there are no global timer functions, so packages that
work there need to use [timers](http://nodejs.org/api/timers.html) module explicitly. Unfortunately they
break on borwserify since timers module does not exists here.

title: IE10: __proto__ in builtins/util.js and builtins/assert.js
body: **proto**, which is not supported on IE10, are used in builtins/util.js and builtins/assert.js. Please replace them with other implementation. Thanks in advance.

title: Required modules are repeated in bundle
body:
I'm not sure if things are working as designed, or if I'm doing something wrong.

In the graph of files required in my application, several files `require('underscore')`. In the generated bundle, the underscore source is listed for each time it's required; it's included in the scope of each requiring file. This obviously creates bloat, and any additions to underscore made in one file (e.g. through `_.mixin`) aren't carried over to any other files. The behavior also goes against the Node.js style, in which required files are cached once.

Am I doing something wrong, or is this correct?

title: verbose is not verbose enough
body:
The `-v` switch only enables printing how many bytes were written.
It would be tremendously useful (at least for me) for a verbose mode (could even be another flag) that prints:
- when the file was generated (on the `-o` mode)
- which file was touched (on the `-w`mode)

I can provide the PR, but I would need some approval / directions. :)

Thanks!
